description:
Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis JEL423 is a fungal pathogen that belongs to the phylum Chytridiomycota. It is the causative agent of the disease chytridiomycosis, which has been responsible for the decline and extinction of numerous amphibian species worldwide.

The JEL423 strain of B. dendrobatidis was isolated from a dead Panamanian golden frog (Atelopus zeteki) collected in 2004. This strain is considered a virulent and highly pathogenic isolate, capable of infecting a wide range of amphibian hosts and causing severe disease.

Morphologically, B. dendrobatidis JEL423 exhibits the characteristic features of the species, including the production of zoospores, which are the motile infective stage, and the formation of sporangia, the reproductive structures that release the zoospores. The pathogen primarily targets the keratinized tissues of amphibians, such as the skin and mouthparts, leading to disruption of essential physiological functions and ultimately, the death of the infected individuals.

The JEL423 strain has been extensively studied in the context of understanding the mechanisms of chytridiomycosis, as well as developing strategies for the conservation and management of amphibian populations affected by this devastating disease.
